question: Question_09
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answer and show your work.
Full simplification of numerical answers is required unless explicitly
stated otherwise.}

Find the area of the largest rectangle which has two vertices on the
\emph{x}-axis and two vertices lie on the graph of the function
$\displaystyle y=8-x^2$ with $\displaystyle -\sqrt{8}\le x \le\sqrt{8}$.
Please justify your answer.
sols:
If the base of the rectangle measures $\displaystyle 2b$, its area is
$\displaystyle A(b) = 2b(8-b^2) = 16b - 2b^3$. To maximize
$\displaystyle A$, we find its critical points by finding
$\displaystyle A'$:

\begin{align*}
A(b) &= 16b - 2b^3 \\
A'(b) &= 16 - 6b^2 \\
\\
0 &= 16 - 6b^2 \\
6b^2 &= 16 \\
b &= \pm \sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}\end{align*}

A simple inspection shows that $b = \sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}$ is a maximum
point of \emph{A} since \emph{A}' changes sign from positive to negative
at that point. The value of \emph{A(b)} at that \emph{b} (i.e., the
maximum area) is:

\begin{align*}
A\left(\sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}\right) &= 2\sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}\left(8-\left(\sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}\right)^2\right) \\
&= { \color{blue} \frac{32}{3} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}} = { \color{blue} \frac{64\sqrt{2}}{3\sqrt{3}}} = { \color{blue} \frac{64\sqrt{6}}{9} }\end{align*}
hints:
Note that if two vertices of the rectangle must lie on the graph of the
function $\displaystyle y=8-x^2$, the two vertices on the x-axis must be
equidistant from the origin.

Suppose that the base of the rectangle measures $2b$ units long. What is
an expression for the area of the rectangle, in terms of $b$?

If the base of the rectangle measures $2b$, its bottom right vertex is
located at $(b, 0)$. Therefore its top right vertex is located at
$(b,8-b^2)$ and it follows that its dimensions are $2b$ by $8-b^2$.
Hence its area is $2b(8-b^2)$. How can we maximize the value of this
expression?
